awd_titl_txt: Characterization of onset of dynamic stall for low Mach number flows
awd_abstract_narration:
Dynamic stall is a common occurrence in maneuvering aerodynamic bodies (e.g., insect/bird wings, helicopter/wind turbine blades, aircraft wings) which is characterized by large increases in unsteady aerodynamic loads. Such loads can lead to catastrophic and fatigue failure of aircraft wings and rotor blades in helicopters and wind turbines. The flow physics affecting the onset of dynamic stall remains unclear and is highly dependent on a large parameter space consisting of geometry, type of maneuver, pitch rate, and Reynolds and Mach numbers. The project will utilize a combination of novel data analysis techniques with high fidelity simulations to understand dynamic stall onset. A clear understanding and characterization of stall onset will pave the way for effective strategies to control and mitigate dynamic stall. The project has transformative implications for a broad range of applications including fixed-wing aircraft and rotating machinery. In addition, broader impacts are expected through curricular enhancements and recruiting women and underrepresented minorities.

The goal of this project is to understand and characterize the onset of dynamic stall using efficient fluid simulations with data-driven analysis methods and experimental validation. The specific objectives are: (1) identify a universal parameter/marker of stall onset through characterization of stall incipience using a suite of physics-based, data-driven, and machine learning approaches, (2) use novel simulation strategies to effectively explore the large parameter space by employing a novel 4-D, space-time framework to remove transients and significantly reduce computation time and by efficiently exploring the parameter space using an adaptive, asynchronous, Bayesian sampling strategy, and 3) validate the universal parameter using experimental data and additional simulations, and investigate the role of acoustic radiation on stall onset. The proposed work consists of intellectual advances in identifying the underlying physical phenomenon that triggers dynamic stall onset, developing an innovative approach to efficiently remove flow transients, and investigating the effect of acoustics on laminar separation bubble dynamics. The project will leverage outreach and workforce development activities ongoing at Iowa State University.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Summary of Research Outcomes

Dynamic stall is a critical challenge in aerodynamic applications, affecting the performance of systems ranging from aircraft/rotorcraft to wind turbines. This NSF-supported research program advanced understanding and predictive capabilities for dynamic stall phenomena by developing innovative stall-onset criteria and methodologies for prediction, including a novel space-time framework for solving unsteady flow problems. New insights were achieved into the onset of dynamic stall, vortex shedding, and the effects of geometric modifications, with broader implications for fluid mechanics and engineering.

Key Accomplishments

1. Development and Validation of Onset Criteria for Dynamic Stall

  • Introduced a vorticity-based criterion, called the boundary enstrophy flux or BEF, to characterize the onset of leading-edge dynamic stall (Journal of Fluid Mechanics, Vol. 935, 2022). The BEF criterion is superior to the current state-of-the-art Leading Edge Suction Pressure (LESP) criterion and indicates earlier stall onset for effective stall mitigation.
  • Demonstrated the capability of the BEF parameter to indicate dynamic stall onset and vortex shedding events in low Reynolds number (Re) flows (Journal of Fluid Mechanics, Vol. 996, No. A11, 2024). It also described the complex unsteady stall behavior at low Re.
  • Evaluated the new dynamic stall onset criteria for mixed and trailing-edge stall (AIAA Journal, Vol. 61, No. 3, 2023; AIAA Science and Technology Forum, San Diego, 2022). The criterion was developed for leading-edge stall. The physical phenomena that determine trailing-edge and mixed-type stall occur away from the leading edge; the BEF criterion can still capture the stall's onset. 
  • Investigated compressibility effects on dynamic stall and demonstrated the efficacy of the stall onset criterion in the compressible flow regime (AIAA Aviation Forum, San Diego, USA, Jun 2023). A manuscript for journal submission is in preparation.
  • Provided in-depth analysis of leading-edge stall phenomena (AIAA Aviation, DC, 2021).
  • Investigated the impact of leading-edge serrations on dynamic stall at low Reynolds numbers (AIAA Science and Technology Forum, San Diego, 2019).
  • Developed multiscale stabilization techniques for solving fluid flow problems in space-time domains (Computer Methods in Applied Mechanics and Engineering; under revision).
  • Demonstrated the use of physics-informed neural networks (PINNs) to accelerate space-time solutions of model parabolic and hyperbolic problems (Journal of Computational Physics; under revision)

2. Numerical and Theoretical Advancements

Broader Impacts

1. Advancement of Knowledge

This research significantly enhanced the theoretical understanding of dynamic stall mechanisms, enabling better predictions, engineering design tools, and ideas on how to control/mitigate stall.

2. Educational Contributions

The project supported the training and mentorship of graduate and undergraduate students in fluid dynamics and numerical methods, fostering future leaders in the field. Multiple undergraduate students and one high-school student were trained through this project.

3. Practical Applications

The outcomes apply to designing and optimizing wind turbines, rotorcraft, and other aerodynamic systems, particularly in unsteady flow and dynamic stall conditions.

Intellectual Merit

The research integrated theoretical and numerical approaches to address critical gaps in understanding dynamic stall. The developed stall-onset criteria and tools are applicable across various regimes and configurations, bridging fundamental insights with practical applications.

Publications and Dissemination

  • Journal of Fluid Mechanics, Vol. 935, 2022: “A vorticity-based criterion to characterise leading edge dynamic stall onset.”
  • Journal of Fluid Mechanics, Vol. 996, No. A11, 2024: “Criteria for dynamic stall onset and vortex shedding in low Reynolds number flows.”
  • AIAA Journal, Vol. 61, No. 3, 2023: “Evaluating dynamic stall onset criteria for mixed and trailing-edge stall.”
  • AIAA Science and Technology Forum, San Diego, CA, 2022: “Evaluating Dynamic Stall Onset Criteria for Mixed and Trailing-Edge Stall.”
  • AIAA Aviation, DC, 2021: “Characterizing onset of leading-edge dynamic stall.”
  • AIAA Science and Technology Forum, San Diego, CA, 2019: “Effect of Leading Edge Serrations on Dynamic Stall at Rec = 30, 000.”
  • Computer Methods in Applied Mechanics and Engineering, Preprint: “Solving fluid flow problems in space-time with multiscale stabilization: formulation and examples.”
  • Journal of Computational Physics, Preprint: “Accelerating Space-Time Methods Using Physics-Informed Neural Networks.”

Challenges and Future Work

While significant milestones were achieved, future efforts will focus on: 

  • Extending the developed criteria to three-dimensional flows. 
  • Demonstrating stall control using the BEF parameter.
  • Enhancing numerical models for real-time predictive capabilities. 
  • Exploring broader applications in energy and aerospace sectors.

Concluding Statement

This research program has made pivotal advancements in understanding dynamic stall and unsteady flow phenomena. The outcomes enhance scientific knowledge while providing actionable tools and methodologies to address critical engineering challenges. These accomplishments set the stage for continued innovation in fluid mechanics and related fields.

 


Last Modified: 12/31/2024
Modified by: Anupam Sharma

Summary of Research Outcomes


Dynamic stall is a critical challenge in aerodynamic applications, affecting the performance of systems ranging from aircraft/rotorcraft to wind turbines. This NSF-supported research program advanced understanding and predictive capabilities for dynamic stall phenomena by developing innovative stall-onset criteria and methodologies for prediction, including a novel space-time framework for solving unsteady flow problems. New insights were achieved into the onset of dynamic stall, vortex shedding, and the effects of geometric modifications, with broader implications for fluid mechanics and engineering.



Key Accomplishments
1. Development and Validation of Onset Criteria for Dynamic Stall

Introduced a vorticity-based criterion, called the boundary enstrophy flux or BEF, to characterize the onset of leading-edge dynamic stall (Journal of Fluid Mechanics, Vol. 935, 2022). The BEF criterion is superior to the current state-of-the-art Leading Edge Suction Pressure (LESP) criterion and indicates earlier stall onset for effective stall mitigation.
Demonstrated the capability of the BEF parameter to indicate dynamic stall onset and vortex shedding events in low Reynolds number (Re) flows (Journal of Fluid Mechanics, Vol. 996, No.A11, 2024).It also described the complex unsteady stall behavior at low Re.
Evaluated the new dynamic stall onset criteria for mixed and trailing-edge stall (AIAA Journal, Vol. 61, No.3, 2023;AIAA Science and Technology Forum, San Diego, 2022). The criterion was developed for leading-edge stall. The physical phenomena that determine trailing-edge and mixed-type stall occur away from the leading edge; the BEF criterion can still capture the stall's onset.
Investigated compressibility effects on dynamic stall and demonstrated the efficacy of the stall onset criterion in the compressible flow regime (AIAA Aviation Forum, San Diego, USA, Jun 2023). A manuscript for journal submission is in preparation.
Provided in-depth analysis of leading-edge stall phenomena (AIAA Aviation, DC, 2021).
Investigated the impact of leading-edge serrations on dynamic stall at low Reynolds numbers (AIAA Science and Technology Forum, San Diego, 2019).
Developed multiscale stabilization techniques for solving fluid flow problems in space-time domains (Computer Methods in Applied Mechanics and Engineering; under revision).
Demonstrated the use of physics-informed neural networks (PINNs) to accelerate space-time solutions of model parabolic and hyperbolic problems (Journal of Computational Physics; under revision)

2. Numerical and Theoretical Advancements



Broader Impacts
1. Advancement of Knowledge


This research significantly enhanced the theoretical understanding of dynamic stall mechanisms, enabling better predictions, engineering design tools, and ideas on how to control/mitigate stall.
2. Educational Contributions


The project supported the training and mentorship of graduate and undergraduate students in fluid dynamics and numerical methods, fostering future leaders in the field. Multiple undergraduate students and one high-school student were trained through this project.
3. Practical Applications


The outcomes apply to designing and optimizing wind turbines, rotorcraft, and other aerodynamic systems, particularly in unsteady flow and dynamic stall conditions.



Intellectual Merit


The research integrated theoretical and numerical approaches to address critical gaps in understanding dynamic stall. The developed stall-onset criteria and tools are applicable across various regimes and configurations, bridging fundamental insights with practical applications.



Publications and Dissemination

Journal of Fluid Mechanics, Vol. 935, 2022: A vorticity-based criterion to characterise leading edge dynamic stall onset.
Journal of Fluid Mechanics, Vol. 996, No.A11, 2024: Criteria for dynamic stall onset and vortex shedding in low Reynolds number flows.
AIAA Journal, Vol. 61, No.3, 2023: Evaluating dynamic stall onset criteria for mixed and trailing-edge stall.
AIAA Science and Technology Forum, San Diego, CA, 2022: Evaluating Dynamic Stall Onset Criteria for Mixed and Trailing-Edge Stall.
AIAA Aviation, DC, 2021: Characterizing onset of leading-edge dynamic stall.
AIAA Science and Technology Forum, San Diego, CA, 2019: Effect of Leading Edge Serrations on Dynamic Stall at Rec = 30, 000.
Computer Methods in Applied Mechanics and Engineering, Preprint: Solving fluid flow problems in space-time with multiscale stabilization: formulation and examples.
Journal of Computational Physics, Preprint: Accelerating Space-Time Methods Using Physics-Informed Neural Networks.




Challenges and Future Work


While significant milestones were achieved, future efforts will focus on:

Extending the developed criteria to three-dimensional flows.
Demonstrating stall control using the BEF parameter.
Enhancing numerical models for real-time predictive capabilities.
Exploring broader applications in energy and aerospace sectors.




Concluding Statement


This research program has made pivotal advancements in understanding dynamic stall and unsteady flow phenomena. The outcomes enhance scientific knowledge while providing actionable tools and methodologies to address critical engineering challenges. These accomplishments set the stage for continued innovation in fluid mechanics and related fields.
